results.title: This Year Was a Disaster. We Hope the Sequel Is Better.
results.abstract: We streamed, we watched, we worried. We also wondered what the catastrophe called 2020 will mean for movies.
results.byline: By A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis

multimedia.caption: People will want to go back to movie theaters when they can, our critics write, but some of the shifts brought about by the pandemic seem lasting.

results.title: She’s Starring Opposite Tom Hanks. She’d Never Heard of Him.
results.abstract: Helena Zengel is a giggly, chatty 12-year-old, whose movie roles take her into psychological territory that even adults would find tough.

results.title: ‘Pieces of a Woman’ Review: A Raw, Ragged Study of a Loss
results.abstract: Vanessa Kirby gives an intensely physical performance as a woman whose life and marriage are upended by the death of a child.

results.title: Jazz Onscreen, Depicted by Black Filmmakers at Last
results.abstract: “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,” “Sylvie’s Love” and “Soul” understand the music and its place in African-American life, a welcome break with Hollywood history.

results.abstract: She remained steadfast in her decades-long fight for justice, but her costumes ranged from a golden-eagle emblem and skirt to a W logo breastplate and leggings.
results.title: Wonder Woman and Her Evolving Look

results.abstract: The co-hosts of Slate’s long-running and influential podcast discuss the “urgency” of art in a crisis and whether Meryl Streep should play Anthony Fauci.
results.title: Reviewing a Wild Year in Art With the ‘Culture Gabfest’

results.title: For His Second Act, Nnamdi Asomugha Made Preparation His Byword
results.abstract: The former pro football player has pushed himself in acting classes, onstage and in films. His latest drama, “Sylvie’s Love,” also meant returning to an early passion: music.

results.abstract: Bullhorn in hand, he roamed the hallways, imposing discipline, expelling “miscreants” and restoring order. Morgan Freeman portrayed him in “Lean on Me.”

results.title: A ‘Great Cultural Depression’ Looms for Legions of Unemployed Performers
results.abstract: With theaters and concert halls shuttered, unemployment in the arts has cut deeper than in restaurants and other hard-hit industries.
